questions.text: (1-3)-B-D glucan assay cannot be used in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive cryptococcosis

 

(1-3) - B - D glucan assay is used for diagnosis of candida infections, invasive aspergillosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

 

It is not useful in case of invasive cryptococcosis and mucor.

 

Cryptococcus species, the causative agents of invasive cryptococcosis, primarily produce glucuronoxylomannan as the major component of their capsule, not (1-3)-β-D-glucan. Therefore, the (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive aspergillosis: Aspergillus species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, and the assay is useful for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia: Pneumocystis jiroveci produces (1-3)-β-D-glucan, making the assay useful for diagnosing PCP.

 

Option D. Invasive candidiasis and candidemia: Candida species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, so the assay is useful for diagnosing these infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis as it does not detect the major components of the Cryptococcus capsule.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which of the following bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. indicus pranii

 

Mw vaccine is extracted from M. indicus pranii

 

The Mycobacterium w (M.w) vaccine is a heat-killed suspension derived from a non-pathogenic mycobacterium: mycobacterium indicus pranii. As an immunotherapy, M.w is used against leprosy; the compound also shares antigens with M. tuberculosis. Its use has shown clinical improvement, rapid bacterial clearance, and enhanced immune responses to Mycobacterium leprae antigens.

 

Administration: 0.1 ml intradermal. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses are injected only on one arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. welchii: This bacterium is known for causing gas gangrene and is not associated with the Mw vaccine.

 

Option C. M. leprae: This bacterium is the causative agent of leprosy, but the Mw vaccine is not derived from M. leprae itself.

 

Option D. M. bovis: This bacterium causes tuberculosis in cattle and can also infect humans, but it is not the source of the Mw vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii and is used in the immunotherapy of leprosy, enhancing immune responses and promoting rapid bacterial clearance.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oocysts

 

Oocysts are the infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii that are shed in the feces of infected cats. These oocysts are highly resistant and can survive in the environment for extended periods, becoming infectious to other hosts, including humans, once they sporulate. When a pregnant woman comes into contact with these oocysts, there is a risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, which can lead to serious congenital abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradyzoites are the form of Toxoplasma that are found within tissue cysts in intermediate hosts.

 

Option B. Tissue cysts, containing bradyzoites, are found in intermediate hosts such as rodents and birds, and not in cat feces.

 

Option C. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite that disseminates throughout the host's tissues during acute infection but are not the form found in cat feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of influenza virus.

 

Rotaviruses - Cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. Genome consists of double-stranded RNA with 11 segments. Segmented RNA helps in easy reassortment of the genome.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Adenovirus can be identified by their icosahedral symmetry with and fibers extruding from the vertices. It is a double stranded DNA virus.

 

 

Option C. Ebola viruses are cylindrical/tubular, and contain viral envelope, matrix, and nucleocapsid components. The virus generally appears in a long, filamentous form, but it can also be “U-shaped,” in the shape of a “6” (the “shepherd’s crook” appearance), or even circular. It is non-segmented and contains single stranded RNA.

 

 

Option D. Rabies viruses belong to Rhabdoviridae which are bullet-shaped viruses with unsegmented single-stranded RNA

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Only

 

The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive Aspergillosis

 

Galactomannan (GM) belongs to a group of polysaccharides which consist of a mannose backbone and a variable number of galactofuran side chains. GM makes up a major part of the cell wall of Aspergillus spp. These galactofuranose-containing polysaccharides vary are secreted in vivo by the fungus during invasive growth. In recent years, the detection of galactofuranose-containing antigens, including GM, has been used for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA).

 

The most commonly used method to determine GM in serum and broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is a double sandwich enzyme-linked immune assay

 

Other Fungal Infections:

 

2. Systemic Candidiasis: Does not typically involve the release of galactomannan.

 

3. Mucormycosis: Caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, which do not produce  galactomannan. It has beta-D-Glucans and mannans that can be used for diagnosis of invasive candidiasis.

 

4. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus species, and the detection of its polysaccharide capsule antigen (cryptococcal antigen) is used for diagnosis, not galactomannan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galactomannan assay is specifically used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, and the presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of this fungal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory test result of leptospira IM reactivity, now presented with breathlessness, fever, and jaundice that worsened after treatment with penicillin. What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

 

The possible diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction typically occurs within 24 hours of starting antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, including syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • The breakdown of the spirochetes after antibiotic administration releases endotoxins and cytokines into the bloodstream.
  • This causes an acute inflammatory reaction, characterized by the release of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-8 (IL-8), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha).

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Symptoms include fever, chills, rigors, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and exacerbation of skin lesions.
  • The symptoms usually begin within 2 hours of antibiotic administration and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistant leptospirosis: This would present with ongoing symptoms despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, but not typically with acute worsening immediately after starting treatment.

 

Option B. Penicillin allergy: This would typically present with urticaria, pruritus, rash, or anaphylaxis, not with the acute inflammatory symptoms described.

 

Option C. Co-infection with dengue: This would be considered if there were signs and symptoms consistent with dengue, such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and hemorrhagic manifestations, but it does not explain the acute worsening after penicillin treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an acute inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of initiating antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, characterized by fever, chills, myalgia, and exacerbation of symptoms due to the release of inflammatory cytokines.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The given image shows a hydatid cyst in the liver. Large, unilocular/multilocular, well-defined, hypodense cysts. Contains multiple internal “daughter” cysts of lower density than “mother” cyst (exocyst). Curvilinear ring-like calcification of pericyst (wall).

 

Causative organism – Echinococcus granulosus

 

Definitive hosts – Dogs, Intermediate host – Sheep, Accidental intermediate host – Human (end stage host)

 

In the liver, the pressure effect of the cyst can produce symptoms of obstructive jaundice and abdominal pain. With biliary rupture, the classic triad of biliary colic, jaundice, and urticaria is observed. Passage of hydatid membranes in the emesis (hydatid emesia) and passage of membranes in the stools (hydatid enterica) may occur rarely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma japonicum: This parasitic worm causes schistosomiasis, primarily affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: This protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and digestive system, not forming cysts in the liver.

 

Option D. Schistosoma mansoni: This parasitic worm also causes schistosomiasis, affecting the intestines and liver, but it does not form hydatid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition shown in the image, characterized by a hydatid cyst in the liver, is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The cysts contain internal daughter cysts and can lead to symptoms related to the pressure effect on the liver and biliary system.

choices.text: Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin
Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin
Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to gram staining and microscopy and appears as shown in the microscopic image given below. Which of the following features/tests will be characteristic of the organism? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catalase negative, optochin sensitive

 

This image is a light micrograph of Gram-stained S. pneumoniae (also known as S. pneumococcus), rounded bacteria (cocci) that usually occur in pairs and sometimes short chains. Their blue color indicates they are Gram-positive.

 

Meningitis occurs when bacteria enter the bloodstream and then cross the blood-brain barrier or through direct contact of meninges with the skin or nasal cavity. The most frequent focus of the infection is the nasopharynx colonized by S. pneumoniae that evades the host immune system. During IPD, the bloodstream becomes invaded, and complement and coagulation systems are activated. Inflammatory mediators are released massively, which makes it easier for the bacteria to cross the blood-brain barrier. Inflammation is responsible for all the typical findings of bacterial meningitis, i.e., CSF pleocytosis.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oxidase and catalase negative, does not ferment inulin: This description is not characteristic of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Oxidase-negative and catalase-negative bacteria include many streptococci, but inulin fermentation is not a typical test used for identifying S. pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Ferments glucose and maltose but not inulin: This characteristic fits some Neisseria species but not S. pneumoniae. S. pneumoniae ferments glucose and sometimes other carbohydrates but is best identified by its optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

 

Option C. Oxidase and catalase positive and does not ferment maltose or glucose: This describes certain gram-negative bacteria, such as Neisseria species, which do not fit the description of S. pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of bacterial meningitis, is characterized by being catalase-negative, optochin-sensitive, and gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci. These features help in its identification and differentiation from other bacterial pathogens.

questions.text: A microbiologist stained a tissue sample and found thin, filamentous bacteria, which resembled Nocardia sp. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the presence of Nocardia? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified acid-fast stain

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid (fast=holding capacity). Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ziehl-Neelsen staining is not specific for Nocardia as it is primarily used for Mycobacteria which require heating of the stain.

 

Option B: Silver impregnation is used for fungi and certain bacteria like Legionella, but not typically for Nocardia.

 

Option C: Albert stain is used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacteria, not for Nocardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified acid-fast stain should be used to confirm the presence of Nocardia due to its weak acid-fast nature and characteristic "beaded" appearance.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligate intracellular, Gram-negative species of Rickettsiales bacteria. It is a zoonotic pathogen transmitted to humans by the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).

 

Ehrlichiosis is evidenced by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions known as morulae in monocytes, which can be observed on a Giemsa-stained blood film.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: By the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum).
  • Symptoms: Patients typically exhibit symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks after tick infection. Early symptoms include fever, headache, malaise, low-back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Some patients may also have myalgias, arthralgias, coughing, pharyngitis, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in mental status.
  • Diagnosis: Besides observing morulae in monocytes, serological tests like indirect fluorescent antibody tests and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are also used for diagnosis.
  • Treatment: TOC Doxycycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), typically associated with rash and vascular endothelial damage, not morulae in monocytes.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever, which also does not present with morulae in monocytes.

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Incorrect. Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), where morulae are found in granulocytes, not monocytes. The presence of morulae in granulocytes is characteristic of Anaplasma infection.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is identified by the presence of morulae in monocytes and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. The proper treatment is doxycycline, and diagnosis is confirmed through blood smear, serological tests, and PCR.

 

GAME – Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: 1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for identification of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive candidiasis

 

1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for the identification of Invasive candidiasis (invasive fungal infections).

 

Beta 1-3 glucan assay test detects the presence of (1-3)-3-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi except cryptococci, mucor, zygomycetes and blastomyces dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhizopus: Rhizopus is a genus of fungi causing mucormycosis, which typically does not produce significant amounts of (1,3)-β-D-glucan. Therefore, the BDG assay is not useful for detecting Rhizopus infections.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Cryptococcus species, which cause cryptococcosis, have a polysaccharide capsule that does not contain (1,3)-β-D-glucan, rendering the BDG assay ineffective for its detection.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis: Mucormycosis is caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, which do not produce (1,3)-β-D-glucan in significant amounts. Thus, the BDG assay is not applicable for diagnosing mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1,3 beta D-glucan is helpful for the identification of invasive candidiasis by detecting the presence of (1,3)-β-D-glucan in the blood, a cell wall component of many pathogenic fungi, but it is not effective for detecting infections caused by fungi such as Cryptococcus, Rhizopus, and Mucormycosis.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

choices.text: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas

questions.text: The CLED medium is preferred over other media for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It inhibits proteus swarming

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

 

Proteus species are a common cause of UTI and produce swarming on ordinary medias leading to difficult isolation of other important urinary pathogens

 

Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, it changes to yellow in case of acid production during fermentation of lactose or changes to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria build yellow colonies. Bacteria which decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and build deep blue colonies.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus. CLED media does not specifically promote the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus.
 

 

Option C. It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria: This is also true for CLED medium but not the reason why it is specifically used for urinary pathogens. Bromothymol blue is the indicator used in the agar, changing to yellow in case of acid production during lactose fermentation or to deep blue in case of alkalinization. Lactose-positive bacteria form yellow colonies, while bacteria that decarboxylate L-cystine cause an alkaline reaction and form deep blue colonies.

 

Option D. It promotes the growth of Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can grow on CLED medium, it is not specifically promoted by this medium compared to the growth of Candida, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystine-Lactose-Electrolyte-Deficient (CLED) medium is a differential medium used for the isolation and enumeration of bacteria from urine. The medium supports the growth of all urinary potential pathogens and provides distinct colony morphology. It supports the growth of urinary pathogens and contaminants and gives good colonial differentiation without the spread of Proteus species due to its lack of electrolytes.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ß-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood culture

 

The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, remitting fever, bradycardia, and a history of eating meals outside suggest a diagnosis of typhoidal salmonella. In the early phase of this infection, particularly within the first week, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a blood culture. Blood cultures are most effective in detecting Salmonella bacteria during the initial week of illness, which aligns with the patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Early detection through blood culture is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is typically performed in the second week of illness when antibodies against Salmonella begin to rise. Since the patient is only 4 days into the illness, the Widal test is not the most reliable at this stage.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures may become positive later in the course of typhoid fever, typically in the third or fourth week. It is not useful in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures are generally useful in the later stages of typhoid fever, around the third week. They are not as effective for early detection within the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: Identify the condenser? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B

 

B: The condenser is located beneath the microscope stage and is used to focus light onto the specimen. It typically contains lenses that gather and concentrate light from the illuminator and direct it through the specimen for optimal viewing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This is the coarse focusing knob, which is used to bring the specimen into general focus by moving the stage up and down.

 

Option B. C: This represents the objective lenses, which are used to magnify the specimen.

 

Option D. D: This is the illuminator, which is the light source that provides illumination for viewing the specimen.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: Bio-film confer resistance to antibiotics by all except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adherence

 

Adherence is a mechanism of bacteria to attach to host cell for penetration. It is not a mechanism of resistance.

 

Mechanisms of biofilm-mediated resistance to antibiotics:

 

  • Mechanical barrier: The lipopolysaccharide biofilms prevent entry of water-soluble drugs.
  • Efflux pumps: These pumps on the biofilms actively excrete drug out.
  • Slow metabolism: Decreased oxygen and nutrients passage through the biofilms slows down the metabolism of bacteria.
  • Anaerobic pathway: Because of the above reason bacteria follow anaerobic metabolism.
  • Persisters: Some bacteria undergo phenotypic modification into dormant, spore-like structure and survive antibiotic insult. These are called as persisters which are activated later.
  • Enzymatic inactivation of drugs by biofilms
  • Genetic adaptation to antibiotic insults
  • Quorum sensing: It is cell to cell signaling among the bacteria to coordinate among themselves for contribution in biofilm synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical barrier: Correct. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents the entry of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Increased excretion of antibiotics: Correct. Efflux pumps in biofilms actively expel antibiotics, reducing their intracellular concentration.

 

Option C. Slow metabolism: Correct. The slow metabolic rate within biofilms makes bacteria less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer resistance to antibiotics through mechanisms such as mechanical barriers, efflux pumps, slow metabolism, and the presence of persisters. Adherence, while important for colonization, does not contribute directly to antibiotic resistance within biofilms.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

choices.text: Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse
Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil
Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following options is wrong about ascaris lumbricoides? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heavy infection is associated with Rectal prolapse

 

Heavy infection with rectal prolapse is NOT associated with Ascaris lumbricoides infection. This clinical manifestation is actually characteristic of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Most infections are asymptomatic: Most Ascaris infections are indeed asymptomatic, particularly in immunocompetent individuals. This is an important clinical feature of ascariasis.

 

Option C. Fertilised unembronated egg takes time to infect after it goes in soil: Ascaris eggs can be either embryonated or unembryonated. The unembryonated eggs require time in soil to develop and become infective. 

 

Option D. Can spread to lungs and cause Asthma like symptoms: Ascaris larvae migrate through the lungs as part of their life cycle (pulmonary phase). During this migration, they can cause respiratory symptoms including cough, wheezing, and asthma-like symptoms, known as Löffler's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rectal prolapse is a characteristic complication of heavy Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection, not Ascaris lumbricoides infection. Ascaris causes pulmonary symptoms during its larval migration phase and is often asymptomatic in its intestinal phase.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obligate intracellular organism

 

Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is an obligate human pathogen and is the etiological agent of gonorrhea.

 

Habitat –

 

  • Human is only the natural host.
  • Found in human urogenital tract.
  • Rectal carriage in healthy individuals.
  • Typically seen in pus cells (intracellular)
  • Found intracellularly in polymorphonuclear leukocytes, or a specific category of white blood cells with varying shapes of nuclei.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase and oxidase positive: This is true for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which tests positive for both catalase and oxidase enzymes.

 

Option B. Pili is a virulence factor: Neisseria gonorrhoeae has pili on its surface, which are essential for its virulence, aiding in attachment and colonization.

 

Option D. Shows twitching motility: Neisseria gonorrhoeae exhibits twitching motility, a type of bacterial movement.

 

Educational Objective

 

Morphology of Neisseria Gonorrhea -

 

  • Gram –ve cocci
  • Shape is spherical
  • Coffee bean shaped diplococcic
  • Usually seen in pairs with adjacent sides flattened
  • LPS has highly branched basal oligosaccharide structure
  • Contains fimbriae
  • Possess pili on the surface
  • Motile (Twitching motility)
  • Non-capsulated
  • Non-sporing

 

It is catalase and oxidase positive.

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

 

HS-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis.

 

Other investigations that can help include:

 

  • CSF examination
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

 

The image shows coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture in chick embryos: HSV-1 doesn’t grow well on Chick embryo line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

 

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PC assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have been approved for diagnostic purposes of Clostridium difficile infection due to high sensitivity, specificity and rapid turnaround time.

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

 

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin- producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or ELISA, or pseudo membranes seen in the colon.

 

Other diagnostic methods include:

 

  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure strain isolation from culture: Stool culture on selective media can identify C. difficile. However, it is not the best method due to longer turnaround times and the need for specialized techniques. It is highly sensitive but less practical for rapid diagnosis. Also the mere presence of clostridium difficile does not suggest infection with the organism unless toxin production is checked.

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence:

Immunofluorescence can be used for detecting C. difficile antigens. It is less commonly used due to the complexity of the procedure and lower sensitivity compared to PCR.

 

Option D. Toxin Detection by ELISA: ELISA can detect toxins in stool samples. Although it is a useful method, it is less sensitive and specific compared to PCR, making it a secondary choice for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amikacin

 

Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever as it is ineffective in clinical infections.

 

Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin: This macrolide antibiotic is commonly used for treating typhoid fever, especially in cases where fluoroquinolone resistance is present.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic, it has been a standard treatment for typhoid fever, though resistance to this class is increasing.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This third-generation cephalosporin is used to treat typhoid fever, particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant Salmonella typhi.

 

Educational Objective:


Amikacin is not effective in the treatment of typhoid fever, despite its efficacy in vitro against Salmonella.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: Most common cause of diarrhoea in children: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

Rotavirus is consistently recognized as the most common cause of severe diarrheal disease in children worldwide. It is particularly significant in infants and young children, causing acute gastroenteritis. The virus primarily affects the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to malabsorption and secretory diarrhea. Rotavirus infection is characterized by:

 

  • Severe watery diarrhea
  • Vomiting
  • Fever
  • Abdominal pain
  • Rapid dehydration, especially in young children

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Incorrect because while E. coli (particularly ETEC and EHEC strains) is an important cause of diarrhea in children, it is not the most common causative agent. E. coli typically causes traveler's diarrhea and some specific syndromes like hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

Option C. Ascaris: Incorrect because although Ascaris lumbricoides can cause various gastrointestinal symptoms, it is primarily a helminthic infection that doesn't typically present with diarrhea as the main symptom. Most Ascaris infections are actually asymptomatic.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect because while Shigella is an important cause of dysentery in children, it typically causes bloody diarrhea with mucus and is not the most common overall cause of childhood diarrhea. It is more associated with poor sanitation and hygiene conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe diarrheal disease in infants and young children worldwide.

 

Agents causing Traveler's diarrhea

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

choices.text: Rocky mountain spotted fever

questions.text: Which disease causes the lesion shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

The lesion shown in the image is eschar. It is seen in scrub typhus.

 

Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the rickettsial bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

It is transmitted to humans by the bite of the larva of trombiculid mites. Later it causes disseminated vasculitis and perivascular inflammation ultimately leading to significant vascular leakage leading to end-organ injury.

 

Clinical features usually arise after an incubation period of 6-21 days and manifest as fever, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. An eschar which usually begins as a primary papular lesion later crusts to form a black ulcer with central necrosis is a distinct feature of scrub typhus although its presence varies in different regions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: A classic case of Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) involves a rash that appears 2-4 days after the onset of fever as small, flat, pink, macules on the wrists, forearms, and ankles and spreads to include the trunk and sometimes the palms of hands and soles of feet.

 

Option B: Malaria is a protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium species characterized by periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option D: COVID-19 is a highly contagious viral disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

 

Educational Objective

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by an eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with fever and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 µm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptosporidium

 

The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy show oocysts of Cryptosporidium.

 

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite. The two cryptosporidium species responsible for traveller’s diarrhoea are C. hominis and C. parvum.

 

 

Sporulated oocysts, containing 4 sporozoites, are excreted by the infected host through feces image (and possibly other routes such as respiratory secretions).

 

Transmission of Cryptosporidium spp. occurs mainly through ingestion of fecally contaminated water (e.g., drinking or recreational water) or food (e.g., raw milk) or following direct contact with infected animals or people.

 

Following ingestion (and possibly inhalation) by a suitable host image, excystation occurs. The sporozoites are released and parasitize the epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract (and possibly the respiratory tract).

 

In these cells, usually within the brush border, the parasites undergo asexual multiplication (schizogony or merogony) and then sexual multiplication (gametogony) producing microgamonts (male) image and macrogamonts (female).

 

Upon fertilization of the macrogamonts by the microgametes that rupture from the macrogamont, oocysts develop and sporulate in the infected host.
