Zygotes give rise to two different types of oocysts (thick-walled and thin-walled. Thick-walled oocysts are excreted from the host into the environment, whereas thin-walled oocysts are involved in the internal autoinfective cycle and are not recovered from stools.

 

Oocysts are infectious upon excretion, thus enabling direct and immediate fecal-oral transmission.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Isospora (now Cystoisospora): Isospora belli oocysts are larger, measuring about 20-30 µm by 10-19 µm. They typically contain two sporocysts, each with four sporozoites. Isosporiasis is less common than cryptosporidiosis and presents with gastrointestinal symptoms in immunocompromised individuals. Isospora oocysts are acid-fast but larger than Cryptosporidium.

 

Option B. Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts are also coccidian parasites but are slightly larger, measuring about 8-10 µm in diameter. Cyclospora infections can cause prolonged diarrhea but are distinguished by their size and autofluorescence under ultraviolet light, which is different from Cryptosporidium.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites that also cause diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients. However, their spores are much smaller (1-2 µm) and they do not exhibit the same morphological characteristics as Cryptosporidium oocysts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are small (4-8 µm) coccidian parasites responsible for causing diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are identified in stool samples by their size and acid-fast staining properties.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: The given life cycle is suggestive of which of the following viruses? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B

 

The given life cycle is of the hepatitis B virus.

 

Steps:

 

  • The infectious virion attaches to cells and uncoating occurs.
  • Cell enzymes in the hepatocytes convert dsDNA to covalently closed circular double-stranded DNA (cccDNA)
  • HBV mRNA and pre-genome RNA is synthesized using cDNA as a template.
  • pre-genome RNA is encapsidated by packaging signal into new core particles.
  • These new core particles are templates for HBV reverse transcriptase.
  • Negative-strand DNA is synthesized by viral polymerase by reverse transcription.
  • The cores bud from the pre-Golgi membranes, acquiring HBAg-containing envelopes.
  • Once viral particles are assembled, they either exit the cell or cause reinfection of the same cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV: HIV is an RNA virus with a life cycle that involves reverse transcription of RNA into DNA, integration into the host genome, and the production of new virions. The depicted life cycle does not match HIV's replication cycle.

 

Option C. Influenza: Influenza is an RNA virus with a replication cycle involving the nuclear replication of viral RNA and budding from the plasma membrane. Its life cycle does not involve cccDNA or reverse transcription.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a DNA virus that also forms episomal DNA in the nucleus, but its replication and assembly processes differ from those of HBV, particularly in the use of the Golgi for envelopment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus is characterized by the formation of cccDNA in the nucleus, reverse transcription of RNA to DNA within the core particles, and budding from the pre-Golgi membranes.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: A pus swab should be discarded in which of the following waste containers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow bag

 

Pus swabs are considered soiled or infected waste materials. As per biomedical waste management guidelines, any material that is soiled, infected, or contaminated with blood or body fluids should be discarded in yellow bags. The yellow bag is specifically designated for:

 

  • Soiled waste
  • Items contaminated with blood
  • Body fluid contaminated items
  • Laboratory waste
  • Microbiological waste
  • Other infected materials

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Red bag: Incorrect because red bags are specifically meant for plastic waste materials such as IV sets, syringes (without needles), catheters, and other plastic medical items.

 

Option C. Black bag: Incorrect because black bags are designated for non-infectious general waste from hospitals such as papers, packaging materials, cartons, and food waste. These materials pose no infection risk.

 

Option D. Blue bag: Incorrect because blue bags/containers are meant for broken or discarded glass items, including:

 

  • Broken glassware
  • Medicine vials
  • Ampoules
  • Other glass materials used in healthcare settings

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yellow bags are designated for soiled and infected waste materials in biomedical waste management, including pus swabs and other contaminated materials.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycetoma

 

The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

 

Mycetoma is an uncommon chronic granulomatous infective disease of the skin/dermis and subcutaneous tissues. “Madura Foot” or “Maduramycosis,” it is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by the filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

 

It is characterized by a triad of tumefaction, draining sinuses and the presence of colonial grains in the exudates. It is seen commonly in people who walk barefoot. Eumycetoma is more common in Northern India, while Actinomycetoma is more common in Southern India.

 

The two main groups of mycetoma are the Actinomycotic and Eumycotic groups. Actinomycetoma is caused by a group of filamentous bacteria which include Nocardia and Streptomyces species. The Nocardia species include Nocardia asteroids, Nocardia braziliensis and Nocardia caviae. The Streptomyces species include Streptomyces madurae, Streptomyces pelletieri and Streptomyces somaliensis.

 

The color of the grains found in the discharge is indicative of the species and helps to initiate appropriate treatment.

 

The foot is the most commonly affected and the dorsal aspect of the left foot for unexplained reasons is more affected.

 

The grains are histologically seen as sulfur granules surrounded by neutrophils which lead to a purulent tissue reaction containing fibroblasts. This prevents the antibiotic from acting on the micro-organisms, hence the need for debridement in certain cases.

 

Combined drug therapy is preferred to a single drug therapy to avoid resistance and any residual infection.

 

Surgical debridement, followed by prolonged appropriate antibiotic therapy for several months is required for actinomycetoma while a combination therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (14 mg/kg, twice daily), dapsone (1.5 mg/kg, twice daily) and streptomycin (14 mg/kg) has been used along with Rifampicin for resistant cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule and does not exhibit the characteristic draining sinuses and grains seen in mycetoma.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Nocardia can cause mycetoma (specifically actinomycetoma), but in the context of the broad diagnosis, mycetoma is the more inclusive and accurate term.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, usually presents with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels rather than multiple sinuses and grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma is characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and colonial grains in exudates, and is common among individuals who walk barefoot. The diagnosis is supported by clinical presentation, histology, and the color of the grains. Treatment involves surgical debridement and prolonged antibiotic therapy for actinomycetoma or antifungal therapy for eumycetoma.

questions.text: A 20- year male had a pustule which rapidly progressed to necrotizing fascitis. On microscopy findings were seen. What is the most likely organism involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The diagnosis of Streptococcus pyogenes is supported by:

 

  1. Clinical presentation: Pustule rapidly progressing to necrotizing fasciitis
  2. Microscopy findings: Gram-positive cocci arranged in chains
  3. Necrotizing fasciitis is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), followed by Staphylococcus aureus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • While it can cause necrotizing fasciitis, it appears as gram-positive cocci in clusters
  • Not consistent with the chain arrangement seen in the microscopy image

 

Option C. Enterococcus:

 

  • Appears as gram-positive cocci in pairs
  • Not typically associated with necrotizing fasciitis
  • More commonly causes urinary tract infections and endocarditis

 

Option D. Micrococcus:

 

  • Appears as gram-positive cocci in tetrads
  • Not a common pathogen
  • Rarely causes human infections
  • Usually a contaminant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus):

 

  1. Is the most common cause of necrotizing fasciitis
  2. Appears microscopically as gram-positive cocci in chains
  3. Can progress rapidly from a superficial infection to deep tissue involvement

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given statement that antibody affinity is higher in the primary immune response and lower in the secondary immune response is incorrect. The correct comparison should be:

 

  • Primary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of the first contact with an antigen. It typically involves a longer lag period (4-10 days) before antibodies are produced. The initial antibodies produced are primarily IgM, with lower affinity for the antigen.
  • Secondary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of subsequent exposures to the same antigen. It involves a shorter lag period (1-3 days) due to the presence of memory cells. The antibodies produced are primarily IgG, which have higher affinity for the antigen compared to those produced in the primary response. The secondary response is more rapid and robust, producing higher levels of antibodies that persist for a longer period.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lag period: Correctly identified; the primary immune response has a longer lag period (4-10 days), while the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-3 days).

 

Option B. Antibody response: Correctly identified; the secondary immune response is more potent than the primary immune response.

 

Option C. Isotype generated: Correctly identified; the primary response mainly produces IgM, while the secondary response mainly produces IgG.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

 

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Wei's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver.

 

Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia ( aka Fagets sign) can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya: Typically presents with fever, severe joint pain, and rash, not prominently featuring jaundice or hepatic involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue hemorrhagic fever: While this can present with fever and potential liver involvement, the hallmark is severe bleeding and plasma leakage.

 

Option D. Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A: Generally presents with jaundice and neurological symptoms due to liver dysfunction but does not typically include calf pain or conjunctival suffusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of fever, jaundice, muscle pain, and conjunctival suffusion, especially if there is a history of exposure to potentially contaminated water. Recognizing these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 µm cysts are visible. Identify the organism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

Cyclospora cayetanensis is a coccidian parasite that causes the gastrointestinal disease cyclosporiasis. The organism produces oocysts that are 8-10 µm in diameter, which can be detected by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. The oocysts exhibit a variable acid-fast staining property and can also autofluoresce under ultraviolet light.

 

Cyclospora oocysts have the following characteristics:

 

  • Size: 8-10 µm in diameter.
  • Staining: They show variable acid-fast staining.
  • Autofluorescence: They exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Isospora: Isospora (now known as Cystoisospora) produces larger oocysts, typically 20-30 µm in size, and contains two sporocysts with four sporozoites each. It does not match the 8-10 µm size described.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller, measuring 4-6 µm in diameter, and consistently exhibit acid-fast staining and bright auramine fluorescence. They do not match the size range described.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are a group of spore-forming unicellular parasites that do not fit the description of having 8-10 µm oocysts visible with Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which of the following is an immunologically privileged site? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminiferous tubule

 

The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.

 

Sites with immune privilege are anatomical regions that are naturally less subject to immune responses than most other areas of the body. So, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.

 

Other examples:

 

  • Anterior chamber of the eye
  • Cornea
  • Testes
  • Brain except at area postrema where blood brain barrier is absent

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Area postrema: This region of the brain lacks the blood-brain barrier and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Option C. Optic nerve: While the optic nerve is part of the central nervous system, it is not classified as an immunologically privileged site like the brain or anterior chamber of the eye.

 

Option D. Loop of Henle: This structure is part of the kidney's nephron and is not considered an immunologically privileged site.

 

Educational Objective:


The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site, protecting developing sperm from immune system attack.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

choices.text: Sporothrix schencki
Corynebacterium minutissimum
Nocardia brasiliensis

questions.text: On inoculation in the skin, all of the following organisms can lead to dermal, subcutaneous, and lymphatic involvement except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corynebacterium minutissimum

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes a localized infection of the stratum corneum called erythrasma and does not involve the dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic tissues.

 

Details of Erythrasma:

 

  • Pathogen: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Common Sites: Axillae, groin, and other intertriginous areas
  • Clinical Features: Presents as well-demarcated, reddish-brown patches that can be mistaken for fungal infections.
  • Predisposing Factors: More common in diabetics and elderly individuals.
  • Diagnosis: Can be confirmed with Wood's lamp examination (coral-red fluorescence) and gram staining.
  • Growth Characteristics: This lipophilic corynebacterium grows readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, characterized by nodular lymphangitis. The infection can spread via lymphatic channels leading to a linear chain of nodules.

 

Option C. Nocardia brasiliensis: Causes nocardiosis, which can involve skin, subcutaneous tissues, and lymphatics, leading to nodular lymphangitis and abscess formation.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes a cutaneous infection that can progress along lymphatic channels leading to nodular lymphangitis, commonly seen in fish tank granuloma.

 

Educational objective

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum, the causative agent of erythrasma, is limited to superficial skin infections and does not cause dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic involvement.

 

Nodular lymphangitis, the most common causes include:

 

  1. Sporothrix schenckii
  2. Nocardia brasiliensis
  3. Mycobacterium marinum
  4. Leishmania brasiliensis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings
All pathogenic strains are urease positive

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Cryptococcus, except? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD4 count greater than 500

 

Cryptococcus infection occurs when CD4 counts fall below 100 cells/microliter. This makes option d incorrect as Cryptococcus infections do not occur at CD4 counts greater than 500. The infection is strongly associated with severe immunocompromise, particularly in AIDS patients with very low CD4 counts (<100 cells/μL).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary cryptococcus is AIDS defining: Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is considered an AIDS-defining illness. When Cryptococcus spreads beyond the lungs in HIV patients, it signifies advanced immunosuppression and meets criteria for AIDS diagnosis.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus gatti is Associated with bird droppings: While Cryptococcus neoformans is the more commonly known species, Cryptococcus gatti is also associated with bird droppings, particularly pigeon excreta. Both species can be found in soil contaminated with bird droppings.

 

Option C. All pathogenic strains are urease positive: All pathogenic strains of Cryptococcus are urease positive. This is an important diagnostic feature used to identify Cryptococcus species in laboratory testing. The urease test helps differentiate Cryptococcus from other yeasts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cryptococcal infections occur at CD4 counts less than 100 cells/microliter, not at counts greater than 500. This is a crucial diagnostic criterion for suspecting cryptococcal infection in HIV/AIDS patients.

questions.text: Identify the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The above image shows giardia lamblia.
  • Cysts are resistant forms and are responsible for transmission of giardiasis. Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces (diagnostic stages). The cysts are hardy and can survive several months in cold water.
  • Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water, food, or by the fecal-oral route (hands or fomites).
  • In the small intestine, excystation releases trophozoites (each cyst produces two trophozoites).
  • Trophozoites multiply by longitudinal binary fission, remaining in the lumen of the proximal small bowel where they can be free or attached to the mucosa by a ventral sucking disk.
  • The cysts are infectious when passed in the stool or shortly afterward, person-to-person transmission is possible.
  • Giardia lamblia exists in:
    • Infective form - Quadrinucleate cyst
    • Tennis racket shaped trophozoite is actively motile with central axostyle with pair of nuclei
    • Oval shaped cyst denoted with cyst wall

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba dispar: Morphologically similar to E. histolytica but is non-pathogenic and does not cause invasive disease.

 

Option C. Balantidium coli: The only ciliate known to infect humans, characterized by large size and the presence of cilia.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebiasis, with cysts and trophozoites distinguishable by their size and internal structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia in its cyst form, is the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated water, food, or fecal-oral route.

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

 

The eggs of hookworm are:

 

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round to oval, thick-shelled, and often bile-stained. They have a rough, mammillated outer layer.

 

Option B. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis eggs are usually not seen in stool samples because they hatch within the intestine. The diagnostic stage is the rhabditiform larva found in the stool.

 

Option C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and have a thick, colorless shell. They are typically detected using the "Scotch tape" method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

choices.text: Western blot
Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following method is employed to measure the viral load? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Real time PCR

 

A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time). Fluorescence is measured after each cycle and the intensity of the fluorescent signal reflects the momentary amount of DNA amplicons in the sample at that specific time. Commonly used for viral load quantification of HIV, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, and CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay is primarily used to detect antigens or antibodies in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option B. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option D. Immunoelectrophoresis: This method is used to separate and identify proteins based on their antigen-antibody interactions and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Real-time PCR measure viral load
  • Western blotting – detects protein.
  • ELISA - detect antigens of infectious agents
  • Immuno electrophoresis – separates antigen following antigen antibody reaction

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who received a kidney transplant a decade ago is presently under immunosuppressive treatment. He reports experiencing a persistent cough and shortness of breath over the past week. Microscopic examination of his sputum reveals the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the probable diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • The presented clinical scenario, coupled with the microscopy revealing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, strongly indicates the presence of invasive candidiasis.
  • Candida albicans has a unique ability to transform frequently between three phenotypic forms in the tissue: yeast, pseudohyphae, true hyphae. This property helps it to evade host defense system.
  • Invasive candidiasis results from hematogenous or local spread of the fungi.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor shows, broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching.

 

Option B. Aspergillus shows septate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive candidiasis is characterized by the presence of gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in tissue or clinical specimens, especially in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennel worker

 

The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Parasite eggs are passed in the feces of infected animals (cats, dogs) into the soil, where the larvae hatch out. Hence kennel workers are at high risk.

 

This condition also known as creeping eruption (ground itch) is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

On coming in contact with human skin, the larvae penetrate the skin to cause infection.

 

In normal animal host, the larvae are able to penetrate the deeper layers of the skin by reaching there via circulation.

 

Once they enter intestine, they mature sexually and lay more eggs that are then excreted to repeat the cycle.

 

However, in a human host, which is an accidental host for the parasite, the larvae are unable to penetrate the basement membrane to invade the dermis, so that the disease remains confined to the outer layers of the skin.

 

The larvae produce itching papules, which develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis. With the movements of the larva in the skin, the lesion also shifts, hence the name "creeping eruption''. Scratching may lead to secondary bacterial infection.

 

Transient creeping eruptions may be produced sometimes by the human hookworm, Necator americanus. Gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce larva migrans, where the lesions are deeper, subcutaneous or in the muscles. Loeffler's syndrome may occur in one-fourth to one-half of the cases.

 

A rapidly moving lesion is produced by Strongyloides stercoralis particularly in immune persons. This is known as larva currens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lifeguard in a swimming pool: This occupation does not typically involve exposure to soil contaminated with animal feces.

 

Option C. Veterinarian: While veterinarians do work with animals, they are less likely to be exposed to soil contaminated with the specific nematodes causing cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Poultry Worker: This occupation involves working with birds, which are not typically hosts for the nematodes causing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans, caused by nematode larvae from Ancylostoma species, is commonly associated with occupations that involve close contact with contaminated soil and animal feces, such as kennel workers.

 

Additional Information
